awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of an Inductively Coupled Plasma-Mass Spectrometer for Quantitative Elemental Analysis of Natural and Engineered Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. The University of Oregon at Eugene is acquiring an ion chromatograph, inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometer (IC-ICP-MS) to support Professor Shannon Boettcher and colleagues Krista McGuire and Matthew Polizzotto. In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species in complex matrices. In a typical experiment, the components flow into a mass spectrometer where they are ionized, and the ion masses are measured. This highly sensitive technique allows detection and determination of the structure of molecules in a complex mixture. The ionization using the inductively coupled plasma allows detection of metal ions and several non-metals present in very small concentrations. The ion chromatograph component allows separation of metal ions from mixtures, thus improving the characterization of the various components. The acquisition strengthens the research infrastructure at the university and regional area since this technology is accessible to students, faculty and researchers throughout several departments such as Chemistry, Biochemistry, Materials Science Institute, Earth Sciences, Biological Sciences and Anthropological Sciences. The team is designing a research program to train new PhD students to be mentors to K-12 students, by showing them how to quantify metal ion content in soil and water sources and a plan to support academic and industrial partnerships through the facility denominated Center for Advanced Material Characterization at Oregon (CAMCOR) where the instrument is located.

The award of the IC-ICP-mass spectrometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It is especially useful to determine species that function as electrocatalysts and for the study of aquifer mineral complexity and redox reactivity. The instrumentation is also used to investigate processes underlying biotransformation of arsenic and other contaminants in aquifers as well as plant-soil-microbial associations contributing to maintenance of tree diversity and nutrient cycling in tropical forests. The instrument also serves researchers assessing interactions of metal ions with nucleic-acid biomolecules and the preparation of precision-engineered nanoparticles. The mass spectrometer aids characterization of trace elements in volcanic and hydrothermal minerals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Overview

The acquisition of an Inductively Coupled Plasma-Mass Spectrometer (ICP-MS) with an integrated Ion Chromatography (IC) system has significantly expanded analytical capabilities at the University of Oregon. Housed in the Center for Advanced Materials Characterization in Oregon (CAMCOR), this instrumentation has facilitated precise trace elemental analysis across diverse scientific disciplines, including electrochemistry, materials science, environmental geochemistry, and biomedical research. Moreover, the impact of this facility extends beyond fundamental research, supporting workforce training and industry engagement while addressing challenges in energy, environmental remediation, and biomedicine.

Advancing Scientific Discovery

ICP-MS has played a pivotal role in electrochemistry and materials science, offering valuable insights into the composition and stability of catalysts, thin films, and electrolytes. In studies of water oxidation catalysts, ICP-MS enabled precise quantification of iron incorporation in nickel-based oxides, revealing that Fe adsorption at surface sites is a primary driver of catalytic activity (Nature Communications). Further applications in perovskite nickelates demonstrated that trace Fe incorporation fundamentally alters catalyst activation, leading to enhanced performance in oxygen evolution reactions (Journal of Catalysis). A study on Fe-free KOH electrolyte purification demonstrated how residual Ni and Co species can be effectively removed using nanofiltration techniques, enabling precise analysis of catalyst behavior without contamination effects (ChemElectroChem). Additionally, ICP-MS has been instrumental in analyzing catalyst degradation in anion-exchange membrane electrolysis, revealing how soluble Fe species accelerate performance deterioration by interacting with catalyst surfaces and ionomer networks (Advanced Materials). Taken together, these studies underscore the critical role of ICP-MS in advancing fundamental electrochemical research. The ability to accurately detect and quantify elemental compositions at trace levels enables researchers to gain mechanistic insights into catalyst stability and degradation.

ICP-MS has enabled key advancements in bioinorganic chemistry and chemical systhesis technologies. Time-dependent studies on oxaliplatin and its derivatives have shown that their cytotoxic effects arise not only from DNA damage but also through inhibition of ribosome biogenesis (ACS Chemical Biology). This work revealed that the rate and extent of nucleolar stress induction vary with subtle changes in Pt(II) ligand structures, highlighting the need for precise elemental analysis. Further research on DACH-functionalized Pt(II) compounds demonstrated that modifying ring substituents at specific positions alters their ability to induce nucleolar stress, emphasizing the structural sensitivity of platinum-based compounds (ChemBioChem). ICP-MS was used to quantify platinum accumulation in whole cells and nuclear fractions, revealing that cellular uptake does not directly correlate with stress induction, suggesting a more selective molecular mechanism. In collaboration with Oak Ridge National Laboratory, ICP-MS was used to quantify anion selectivity in liquid-liquid extraction systems, demonstrating a reversal of the classical Hofmeister effect. These findings, published in Chemical Science, highlight the instrument’s essential role in elucidating mechanisms of ion extraction and separation processes.

In ophthalmology, the instrument was used to quantify copper content in biodegradable ocular implants, a crucial step in developing a non-invasive therapy for keratoconus, a degenerative eye disease that currently lacks effective treatment options. In biology, ion chromatography coupled with ICP-MS has provided new insights into bacterial metabolism by tracking metabolic byproducts in bacterial cultures. This research has informed understanding of how pathogens adapt to host environments, particularly in chronic infections such as cystic fibrosis, and has implications for improving antibiotic efficacy. ICP-MS has also been central to the study of advanced materials. Researchers have applied it to characterize elemental distributions in complex materials such as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), revealing critical insights into charge transport and structural dynamics. 

Broader Impacts:

The ICP-MS facility has provided extensive training opportunities, equipping students and researchers with expertise in trace elemental analysis. Over the course of the project, graduate and undergraduate students have been trained in ICP-MS operation, gaining hands-on experience in sample preparation, data acquisition, and quantitative analysis. The superuser training program has enabled graduate students, including Liam Twight and Kseniya Vialichka, to develop technical proficiency, facilitate user training, and engage in industry collaborations. These experiences have not only advanced their research skills but also prepared them for careers in academia and industry. The instrument has also been integrated into coursework, particularly in electrochemical technology master’s programs, where students gain direct exposure to state-of-the-art analytical techniques.

Industry engagement has been a significant aspect of the facility’s impact. Companies including Hexion and Actylis have utilized ICP-MS for materials characterization and chemical analysis, underscoring the instrument’s relevance to commercial applications. Additionally, collaborations with De Nora, HGEN, and NEL Hydrogen have supported efforts to develop next-generation hydrogen production and electrochemical energy storage technologies. These partnerships have facilitated technology transfer and commercialization, bridging the gap between fundamental research and real-world applications.

Conclusion

The NSF-funded ICP-MS facility has established an analytical hub for elemental analysis, supporting fundamental and applied research across multiple disciplines. The instrument’s contributions to scientific discovery, industry partnerships, and workforce training will continue to shape the fields of materials science, electrochemistry, environmental science, and biomedical research for years to come.


Last Modified: 02/14/2025
Modified by: Shannon W Boettcher
